episodes.description: This episode answers the question “what is Agile” and provides a refresh on the differences between the Agile approach to PM and traditional waterfall approaches.  We also have a quick recap on the Agile manifesto and the Agile principles.

69

don't apply, or how much of it we don't

75

think about because we're too busy
thinking in the depths of the code, and

76
00:04:15.986 --> 00:04:20.001
we don't actually think about
the governance of our services and

77

how we deliver our services.

78

So yeah, we could come up with something.

79

And Hawaii sounds fantastic to me.

80

[LAUGH]

81

[LAUGH]
>> Now Jo, what are some

82

of the methodologies that we'll
see being utilized here in Agile?

83
00:04:30.740 --> 00:04:31.870
>> Well, the first thing that we gotta

84
00:04:31.870 --> 00:04:36.950
remember is that Agile is not
actually a methodology in itself.

85
00:04:36.950 --> 00:04:42.034
Agile is not a single approach, it's
a group of methodologies, it's really,

86
00:04:42.034 --> 00:04:46.770
really sort of a pragmatic,
what it says there, pragmatic mindset.

87
00:04:46.770 --> 00:04:50.990
It's all about a flexible
approach to problem, to problem,

88
00:04:50.990 --> 00:04:54.070
to project management,
even not to problem management, and

89
00:04:54.070 --> 00:04:58.640
you'll see here we've got
a group of methodologies there.

90
00:04:58.640 --> 00:05:02.450
And this is not a definitive list.
>> Comprehensive list-

91
00:05:02.450 --> 00:05:03.950
>> Yeah, there are lots and

92
00:05:03.950 --> 00:05:09.470
lots of other methodologies that
may land themselves into Agile.

93
00:05:09.470 --> 00:05:13.720
Agile basically means, well,
pretty much what it says, that it's agile,

94
00:05:13.720 --> 00:05:15.200
it's flexible.

95
00:05:15.200 --> 00:05:20.360
And it's really about delivering
product in a continuous,

96
00:05:20.360 --> 00:05:23.230
continual manner, that's what it's about.

97
00:05:23.230 --> 00:05:25.610
It's not a waterfall approach.

98
00:05:25.610 --> 00:05:29.972
If it was traditional waterfall
approach to product delivery and

99
00:05:29.972 --> 00:05:35.440
to project managements, then we have a set
time period, which is in our generally

100
00:05:35.440 --> 00:05:41.067
somewhere from six months to two, three
years even, I've seen projects last for,

101
00:05:41.067 --> 00:05:46.780
where we start off at the beginning with
defining what it is that our users want.

102
00:05:46.780 --> 00:05:51.640
And then we go through the entire build,
and we go through the entire build in

103
00:05:51.640 --> 00:05:57.059
a very chronological way, and
then we start to, as we've developed,

104
00:05:57.059 --> 00:06:02.155
we then test, and then once we've tested,
then we deploy, and then once we deploy,

105
00:06:02.155 --> 00:06:07.935
we have a period of hand holding, and
then we walk away as a project team.

106
00:06:07.935 --> 00:06:09.881
And that's it, that project is signed off.

107
00:06:09.881 --> 00:06:16.670
Well, waterfall approach works very very
well for very large implementations,

108
00:06:16.670 --> 00:06:20.940
but you see, right at the very beginning
is when we have that user interaction, and

109
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:23.297
then they see nothing
potentially until very end.

110
00:06:24.350 --> 00:06:27.830
So Agile looks at this slightly
differently, and Agile will say well,

111
00:06:27.830 --> 00:06:31.860
okay, we've got to build up momentum,
we've got to allow for

112
00:06:31.860 --> 00:06:35.920
change, which is something that waterfall
projects traditionally don't, and

113
00:06:35.920 --> 00:06:37.810
we've got to be visible.

114
00:06:37.810 --> 00:06:40.710
Because we've got to deliver
visible benefits, but

115
00:06:40.710 --> 00:06:43.320
we've got to deliver
benefits on a regular basis.

116
00:06:43.320 --> 00:06:46.150
And the one thing that we
know is that things change.

117
00:06:46.150 --> 00:06:50.620
I mean, if we started off,
can you imagine, just a complete aside,

118
00:06:50.620 --> 00:06:55.270

120

>> [LAUGH]

121
00:07:01.590 --> 00:07:02.380
>> I mean,

122
00:07:02.380 --> 00:07:05.280
I try to get as much as

123
00:07:05.280 --> 00:07:08.781

124
00:07:08.781 --> 00:07:09.701
>> Well, look, but okay..

125
00:07:09.701 --> 00:07:11.055
>> [LAUGH]

126
00:07:11.055 --> 00:07:12.500
>> You can be cheap when it comes to

00:07:12.500 --> 00:07:16.390

128
00:07:16.390 --> 00:07:18.391

129
00:07:18.391 --> 00:07:19.345

130

00:07:21.150 --> 00:07:22.905

132
00:07:22.905 --> 00:07:24.390

>> Right.

133
00:07:24.390 --> 00:07:27.420
Impatience, that's what this is,
it's just complete impatience..

134
00:07:27.420 --> 00:07:29.640
But I'm hungry for the latest technology.

135
00:07:29.640 --> 00:07:34.220

I want new features.

136
00:07:34.220 --> 00:07:37.940

>> I know, like I said,

137
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:41.255
I think here, in our environment I'm
the exception to that and that's because-

138
00:07:41.255 --> 00:07:42.190
>> [LAUGH]

139
00:07:42.190 --> 00:07:43.060
>> My budget, really.

140
00:07:43.060 --> 00:07:44.890
>> Right, I'm not the only one,

141
00:07:44.890 --> 00:07:45.780
okay?
>> [LAUGH]

142
00:07:45.780 --> 00:07:47.190
>> I'm just gonna walk out of this studio

143
00:07:47.190 --> 00:07:52.399

144
00:07:52.399 --> 00:07:54.541
Yeah, I'm always hungry for
new technology.

145
00:07:54.541 --> 00:07:58.561
And so are our users as well,
and so is our organization.

146
00:07:58.561 --> 00:08:03.391
And it's true to say, and I know that this
is gonna sound a bit like a story sort of

147
00:08:03.391 --> 00:08:08.011

the past few years the rate of technology

148
00:08:08.011 --> 00:08:12.090
change, well, it's become more rapid,
it has increased.

149
00:08:12.090 --> 00:08:15.669
And so our organizations
expect more functionality, and

150
00:08:15.669 --> 00:08:19.917
they expect functionality to be
available to them when they want it.

151
00:08:19.917 --> 00:08:23.720
And they expect it to be available now,
not in three years time.

152
00:08:23.720 --> 00:08:27.070
In three years time, or
in two years time, even.

153
00:08:27.070 --> 00:08:28.530
My needs changed.
>> Right,

154
00:08:28.530 --> 00:08:30.400
it's Moore's law.
>> Right.

155
00:08:30.400 --> 00:08:32.780
>> And we've exceeded his predictions

156
00:08:32.780 --> 00:08:34.962
years ago.
>> Yeah, right.

157
00:08:34.962 --> 00:08:36.642
>> [LAUGH]

158
00:08:36.642 --> 00:08:39.100
>> Agile allows for that, and

159
00:08:39.100 --> 00:08:44.050
that's why we have agile as an approach
to project management, because with that

160
00:08:44.050 --> 00:08:50.300
continuous delivery, then what we're
doing is we are delivering features.

161
00:08:50.300 --> 00:08:54.540
So we're giving our users what they
want in that point in time, but

162
00:08:54.540 --> 00:08:59.750
also we're allowing them to say, okay,
I like that, but can I have it this way?

163
00:08:59.750 --> 00:09:03.240
And when you think about
the way we get our cellphones,

164
00:09:03.240 --> 00:09:09.010
the way that for instance,
that's exactly how we do this now.

165
00:09:09.010 --> 00:09:10.940
We update our operating systems.

166
00:09:10.940 --> 00:09:11.975
And we update our app.

167
00:09:11.975 --> 00:09:14.070
So probably a monthly basis.

168
00:09:14.070 --> 00:09:17.120
And we expect to seeing new
functionality when we do that.

169
00:09:17.120 --> 00:09:19.760
And that's an Agile approach.

170
00:09:19.760 --> 00:09:22.840
So Agile is really sort of pragmatic.

171
00:09:22.840 --> 00:09:25.590
And by pragmatic, I mean,
it's kind of matter of fact.

172
00:09:25.590 --> 00:09:28.460
It's very, it's common sense.

173
00:09:28.460 --> 00:09:31.806
And we just have to accept
the fact that things change.

174
00:09:31.806 --> 00:09:34.860
And so we've got to adapt to that.

175
00:09:34.860 --> 00:09:37.490
And we've got to be able
to accommodate change.

176
00:09:37.490 --> 00:09:41.430
We've got to be able to accommodate
changing customer desires, and

177
00:09:41.430 --> 00:09:44.220
changing customer needs as well.

178
00:09:44.220 --> 00:09:48.080
Which is why we have to have
that flexible approach.

179
00:09:48.080 --> 00:09:50.980
It now is by all the reasons
we've just talked about.

180
00:09:50.980 --> 00:09:55.900
It's difficult to predict what a
customer's going to want in a year's time.

181
00:09:55.900 --> 00:09:57.941
They don't have a year to wait.

182
00:09:57.941 --> 00:10:01.516
So we have to have what we
call a flexible approach

183
00:10:01.516 --> 00:10:06.280
that allows us to adapt as we learn or
rather adapt as we grow.

184
00:10:06.280 --> 00:10:08.837
And adapt as we move through
the project progresses.

185
00:10:10.080 --> 00:10:14.840
Now, I also wanna bring into
the bottom bullet point there that

186
00:10:14.840 --> 00:10:17.950
I've just mentioned
about self-organization.

187
00:10:17.950 --> 00:10:22.870
We talk about collaboration a lot in
Agile, and self-organization is really,

188
00:10:22.870 --> 00:10:23.930
really key.

189
00:10:23.930 --> 00:10:27.202
Because self-organization is
about that collaboration,

190
00:10:27.202 --> 00:10:29.389
it's about the team working together.

191
00:10:29.389 --> 00:10:32.088
It's not having a strict hierarchy and

192
00:10:32.088 --> 00:10:35.456
it's also not being micro-managed,
as well.

193
00:10:35.456 --> 00:10:38.160
People don't perform well when
they're being micro-managed.

194
00:10:38.160 --> 00:10:41.910
If I've got somebody over
my shoulder the whole time.

195
00:10:41.910 --> 00:10:46.600
And watching everything that I do,
I'm not gonna perform particularly well.

196
00:10:46.600 --> 00:10:51.720
Because I'm gonna spend too much time
worrying about what's being thought of me,

197
00:10:51.720 --> 00:10:54.060
and-
>> Right, and personally, I feel like for

198
00:10:54.060 --> 00:10:58.300
me, and I feel like I've observed
this in numerous situations,

199
00:10:58.300 --> 00:11:00.610
where the person that's not micromanaged.

200
00:11:00.610 --> 00:11:03.100
Is going to give a little more.

201
00:11:03.100 --> 00:11:06.740
A little bit extra than what they,
if they have that freedom.

202
00:11:06.740 --> 00:11:09.630
Than if they were micro managed.
>> I want to bring

203
00:11:09.630 --> 00:11:13.190
into this conversation actually
the working from home.

204
00:11:13.190 --> 00:11:13.920
There's a big.

205
00:11:13.920 --> 00:11:17.852
And this by the way,
is kind of outside of Agile.

206
00:11:17.852 --> 00:11:19.606
I'm gonna talk about
this in a little while.

207
00:11:19.606 --> 00:11:23.649
We'll talk about in another episode we'll
talk about teams and their location.

208
00:11:23.649 --> 00:11:29.710
But there is a misconception that working
from home people actually do less.

209
00:11:29.710 --> 00:11:33.950
Well guess what, people actually do
more when they're working from home.

210
00:11:33.950 --> 00:11:38.310
When you're working in your office,
you come in and you will, you'll

211
00:11:38.310 --> 00:11:42.460
it's almost like be in micromanage you
come in and you come in maybe 08:30 AM and

212
00:11:42.460 --> 00:11:47.670
you leave at 1630 or 1700 and
you do your day's work.

213
00:11:47.670 --> 00:11:51.570
When you're working from home, sure,
you might take five minutes to go and put

214
00:11:51.570 --> 00:11:56.640
the washing machine on or to go and grab
yourself some toast or make a cup tea.

215
00:11:56.640 --> 00:11:59.112
I have been in the studio and
that okay [LAUGH].

216
00:11:59.112 --> 00:12:02.899
All right, you might grab five
minutes here and there to do that.

217
00:12:02.899 --> 00:12:04.498
But when you are working from home and

218
00:12:04.498 --> 00:12:08.380
you hate your laptop because of the emails
you go and you will seat on your laptop.

219
00:12:10.110 --> 00:12:12.900
And it doesn't matter what time of day or
night that is.

220
00:12:12.900 --> 00:12:15.930
And I wonder,

00:25:29.904 --> 00:25:33.405
Bear it in mind that with each iteration,

451
00:25:33.405 --> 00:25:37.720

only got up to four weeks.

452
00:25:37.720 --> 00:25:41.242
There's some Agile myths here and
we've already really covered those,

453
00:25:41.242 --> 00:25:45.121
about Agile doesn't require documentation
and it doesn't require planning.

454
00:25:45.121 --> 00:25:49.226

455
00:25:49.226 --> 00:25:53.358
User stories, we're going to get into

456
00:25:53.358 --> 00:25:55.375

457
00:25:55.375 --> 00:25:59.697
Every single user story is going to
be different and it should be unique.

458
00:25:59.697 --> 00:26:03.842
Which means that every single sprint
is going to be a different length.

459
00:26:03.842 --> 00:26:08.516
We say between one and four weeks for
every single sprint but

460
00:26:08.516 --> 00:26:12.455
it could be one week and
it could be for one sprint.

461
00:26:12.455 --> 00:26:17.126
And the next one could be four weeks, and
then the next one could be two weeks.

462
00:26:17.126 --> 00:26:19.449

but

463
00:26:19.449 --> 00:26:22.886
the product owner's the person that
decides what goes in the sprint.

464
00:26:22.886 --> 00:26:26.036
All we know is,
that whatever goes in the sprint,

465
00:26:26.036 --> 00:26:29.647
we've gotta be able to achieve
that in that time period.

466
00:26:29.647 --> 00:26:33.737
Whatever the time period is,
it's got to be achievable.

467
00:26:33.737 --> 00:26:38.349
And here on this particular
slide you've got an overview of

468
00:26:38.349 --> 00:26:40.386
an actual sprint itself.

469
00:26:40.386 --> 00:26:46.168

the person that prioritizes the backlog,

470
00:26:46.168 --> 00:26:47.167
then we plan.

471
00:26:47.167 --> 00:26:50.211
And the team then actually starts
to do the development work.

472
00:26:50.211 --> 00:26:53.231
And every day we have
our daily scrum meeting.

473
00:26:53.231 --> 00:26:56.893
And we also at the end of
the sprint well we'll do a review.

474
00:26:56.893 --> 00:27:02.030
And we'll complete the sprint itself and
then we will either release at

475
00:27:02.030 --> 00:27:07.602
that point in time or we'll not we'll
shelve that until the actual release.

476
00:27:07.602 --> 00:27:11.039
And we do the retrospective,
we look back and we see what's gone wrong.

477
00:27:11.039 --> 00:27:14.799
And when right and
we apply that to our next point.

478
00:27:14.799 --> 00:27:19.665
So in out next episodes then what we're
going to do is we're going to expand

479
00:27:19.665 --> 00:27:20.990
those activities.

480
00:27:20.990 --> 00:27:24.673
The activities of the product
owner actually completes and

481
00:27:24.673 --> 00:27:26.742
that they're responsible for.

482
00:27:26.742 --> 00:27:29.953
And hopefully we'll see you
back in the next episode.

483
00:27:29.953 --> 00:27:31.653
>> Great, thank you for that overview and

484
00:27:31.653 --> 00:27:34.963
introduction into our series here Jo,
and thank you for joining us as well.

485
00:27:34.963 --> 00:27:38.127
But for now we'll sign out,
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

486
00:27:38.127 --> 00:27:39.039
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

487
00:27:39.039 --> 00:27:41.847
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

488
00:27:41.847 --> 00:27:47.584

489
00:27:47.584 --> 00:27:50.197
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

An IT person and

you mentioned about

00:08:07.140 --> 00:08:11.410

00:08:17.230 --> 00:08:20.065
The product owner makes the decisions.

00:08:26.615 --> 00:08:27.291

00:17:27.020 --> 00:17:29.580
And then-

00:17:31.916 --> 00:17:33.131
>> Hm, I know-

00:18:38.230 --> 00:18:39.390
>> Yeah, true.

00:18:39.390 --> 00:18:42.470
>> So that's a different story, and

00:18:42.470 --> 00:18:43.340
this is confusing.

And I'm not gonna pretend that it's easy,
and

this why we take the time to elaborate on

00:18:50.280 --> 00:18:52.530
Because from a development prospective,

00:18:52.530 --> 00:18:55.150

>> Yeah, and I'm developing labs,

00:18:56.850 --> 00:18:59.370

00:18:59.370 --> 00:19:03.630
I'm developing two different things, so in

in that example, we're talking

00:19:06.690 --> 00:19:10.820
But we're also talking about

00:19:10.820 --> 00:19:12.910
Now, the example that I gave you,

00:19:12.910 --> 00:19:17.600

00:19:17.600 --> 00:19:21.556
I'm talking about one story for

332
00:19:21.556 --> 00:19:22.234
>> I think Mary,

and I both want our groceries.

334
00:19:23.709 --> 00:19:26.230
[LAUGH]
>> Right, exactly.

335
00:19:26.230 --> 00:19:30.220
You both want to get your food, so
you both want to be able to eat,

336
00:19:30.220 --> 00:19:33.396
but you just want to
do it a different way.

337
00:19:33.396 --> 00:19:37.850
So the user's story still exactly the same

00:19:37.850 --> 00:19:39.360

339
00:19:39.360 --> 00:19:42.400
But what we're going to do

340
00:19:42.400 --> 00:19:44.870

341
00:19:44.870 --> 00:19:49.180
And then please go back to our episode or

342
00:19:49.180 --> 00:19:53.780
But when we do the user testing, then the

00:19:53.780 --> 00:19:56.980

>> Okay.

344
00:19:56.980 --> 00:19:58.480
>> This is why personas are really

00:19:58.480 --> 00:19:59.210
important.

346
00:20:00.640 --> 00:20:03.430
Because if we don't have
the personas defined,

347
00:20:03.430 --> 00:20:06.690
then what will happen is
we'll just test one thing.

348
00:20:06.690 --> 00:20:11.150
And we'll test the way that Cherokee does

349
00:20:11.150 --> 00:20:13.930
us to test it that way because-

350
00:20:13.930 --> 00:20:14.525
and yeah.

351
00:20:14.525 --> 00:20:17.868
[LAUGH] Yeah and
she has to hear me complain, yeah.

352
00:20:17.868 --> 00:20:20.580
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, right, so we're going to

353
00:20:20.580 --> 00:20:24.680
be testing just the way that Cherokee
wants to use it because we're in IT.

354
00:20:24.680 --> 00:20:27.980
And that's the way that would use it,
and that's the way that we would test.

355
00:20:27.980 --> 00:20:34.752
So if we didn't have Mary's user persona
defined, we would never test it.

356
00:20:34.752 --> 00:20:38.997
And because we would never test it,
then that would make it difficult for

00:20:38.997 --> 00:20:42.700
Mary to then use the product
because she wouldn't know how to.

358
00:20:42.700 --> 00:20:47.380
And that is exactly the same as when we
were talking about being colorblind and

359
00:20:47.380 --> 00:20:50.360
then having to add in
accessibility options.

360
00:20:50.360 --> 00:20:53.950
Because we didn't think about the user
persona right at the very beginning.

361
00:20:55.080 --> 00:21:00.550
So these are why our user personas are so
important to our user stories,

362
00:21:00.550 --> 00:21:05.130
but we have to be able to differentiate
between the user personas and

363
00:21:05.130 --> 00:21:09.010
the functionality within the user stories.

364
00:21:09.010 --> 00:21:14.790
Because if the functionality is different,
then that's a different user story.

365
00:21:16.800 --> 00:21:18.230
Kinda makes sense, right?
>> Yeah,

366
00:21:18.230 --> 00:21:18.935
it does.
>> Yeah?

367
00:21:18.935 --> 00:21:20.140
>> [LAUGH]

368
00:21:20.140 --> 00:21:21.370
>> So our user stories,

369
00:21:21.370 --> 00:21:24.520
then, are created by
lots of different people.

370
00:21:24.520 --> 00:21:29.060
And it has to be done
collaboratively before we can

371
00:21:29.060 --> 00:21:33.460
actually define and agree the user story.

372
00:21:35.770 --> 00:21:38.990
So let's take a look then
at our acceptance criteria.

373
00:21:38.990 --> 00:21:42.980
Because you see, what we've done by
defining the user story is we've also

374
00:21:42.980 --> 00:21:45.260
defined the acceptance criteria.

375
00:21:46.472 --> 00:21:49.230
Then, the acceptance criteria
was what we want to see.

376
00:21:49.230 --> 00:21:55.380
Now, the acceptance criteria for
that particular example that I gave you,

377
00:21:55.380 --> 00:22:01.510
that acceptance criteria is for online
shopping or rather for mobile shopping.

378
00:22:02.570 --> 00:22:06.130
But it describes the features
in the acceptance criteria.

379
00:22:06.130 --> 00:22:10.440
And the story must be included to be
accepted by the user, and of course,

380
00:22:10.440 --> 00:22:14.330
we're gonna have differing, well,
we gonna have the same functionality.

381
00:22:14.330 --> 00:22:20.620
But we're gonna have a different way
of working with those two user stories.

382
00:22:20.620 --> 00:22:24.110
And so we generally put that on
the back of the user story card.

383
00:22:24.110 --> 00:22:27.940
You could log that somewhere differently,
but we generally put it on the back of

384
00:22:27.940 --> 00:22:31.710
the user story card because that's
what we have to test as well.

385
00:22:31.710 --> 00:22:35.430
So you'd pick up the card with the actual
story, and you look at the back and say,

386
00:22:35.430 --> 00:22:37.300
wow, well that's what I'm gonna test.

387
00:22:37.300 --> 00:22:41.554
That's what's going to tell me
whether I'm actually successful,

388
00:22:41.554 --> 00:22:44.060
whether this story is completed or not.

389
00:22:46.905 --> 00:22:51.955
So, remember, that a good story, well,
we've got to invest in a good story.

390
00:22:51.955 --> 00:22:58.405
And again, we covered this when we
looked at our fundamentals series.

391
00:22:58.405 --> 00:23:03.085
A good user story should be
independent of other user stories.

392
00:23:03.085 --> 00:23:07.675
So we should be able to identify
the functionality just for

393
00:23:07.675 --> 00:23:11.190
that user story, but
it should also be negotiable.

394
00:23:11.190 --> 00:23:14.280
A user story is the end result.

395
00:23:14.280 --> 00:23:15.640
It's not the design.

396
00:23:17.864 --> 00:23:20.070
The design needs to be flexible.

397
00:23:20.070 --> 00:23:23.705
The end result should be fairly flexible,

398
00:23:23.705 --> 00:23:26.420
bearing in mind that things
are going to change.

399
00:23:26.420 --> 00:23:28.920
But we may decide that within

400
00:23:28.920 --> 00:23:33.150
a particular piece of functionality
that we might deliver one user story.

401
00:23:33.150 --> 00:23:36.760
And then maybe in a subsequent
iteration or a subsequent sprint,

402
00:23:36.760 --> 00:23:40.130
we might actually deliver another
user story that's fairly similar.

403
00:23:40.130 --> 00:23:43.408
Or we may overwrite that
previous user story.

404
00:23:43.408 --> 00:23:47.440
Ultimately, the story's gotta be
valuable to the customer and not to us.

405
00:23:48.900 --> 00:23:50.250
It's not what we want to deliver.

406
00:23:50.250 --> 00:23:53.859
It's what they want to see, and
it's how they want to use it.

407
00:23:53.859 --> 00:23:59.904
It's got to be a story that we can
deliver within a set period in time,

408
00:23:59.904 --> 00:24:06.485
so this is why we talk about small, and
we talk about estimate at whatever.

409
00:24:06.485 --> 00:24:08.195
We gotta be able to estimate it.
>> [LAUGH]

410
00:24:08.195 --> 00:24:10.868
>> Estimable, that sounds.

411
00:24:10.868 --> 00:24:12.580
>> Estimatable?

412
00:24:12.580 --> 00:24:13.470
>> Estimatable?

413
00:24:15.240 --> 00:24:18.570
Estimable is kind of probably
what we'd use at English.

414
00:24:18.570 --> 00:24:21.470
That's what we use in English but
estimatable.

415
00:24:21.470 --> 00:24:23.328
Yeah, all right, I'm okay, I'm good.
>> [LAUGH]

416
00:24:23.328 --> 00:24:24.432
>> I'm good without one as well.

417
00:24:24.432 --> 00:24:28.030
If that's so easier to say,
put it that way.

418
00:24:28.030 --> 00:24:29.415
We've got to be able to estimate.

419
00:24:29.415 --> 00:24:32.320
[LAUGH] And the length of the user story.

420
00:24:32.320 --> 00:24:34.280
And like I said, it's got to be small.

421
00:24:34.280 --> 00:24:35.820
It's got to fit within an iteration.

422
00:24:35.820 --> 00:24:40.790
And an iteration is well,
between one and four weeks.

423
00:24:40.790 --> 00:24:44.160
Nothing more than that, okay?

424
00:24:44.160 --> 00:24:45.660
And the user story.

425
00:24:45.660 --> 00:24:47.510
Well, you better be able to test it.

426
00:24:47.510 --> 00:24:52.780
Have we actually delivered what
we are supposed to deliver?

427
00:24:52.780 --> 00:24:55.760
Because that's the ultimate test,
isn't it?

428
00:24:55.760 --> 00:24:57.900
Have we achieved what
we set out to achieve?

429

And then, of course,

And what we do is we delivery

00:25:11.660 --> 00:25:15.550
So we deliver that in

00:25:15.550 --> 00:25:18.610
So it's a story that's got
to be slipt basically.

435
00:25:18.610 --> 00:25:20.590
It's too big and it has to be split.

436
00:25:23.250 --> 00:25:27.820
So before we leave for this particular
episode and we are gonna come back in

437

user stories but before we leave,

I really just wanna reinforce

00:25:36.870 --> 00:25:42.440
And it's not something that we

440
00:25:42.440 --> 00:25:47.500
But it goes back to everything
that I say about development and

441
00:25:47.500 --> 00:25:51.530

it's about understanding your business and

442
00:25:51.530 --> 00:25:53.310
understanding your customer.

443
00:25:53.310 --> 00:25:55.510
And unless you actually
understand who your business and

00:25:55.510 --> 00:25:59.910

00:25:59.910 --> 00:26:03.540

00:26:03.540 --> 00:26:07.450
You're only going to be able to deliver
functionality that meets just a portion of

00:26:07.450 --> 00:26:08.970

448
00:26:08.970 --> 00:26:12.710
So, users pesona is a something

00:26:12.710 --> 00:26:16.180
And yet, I see this all

00:26:16.180 --> 00:26:17.510

But when I ask to see,
especially when I'm doing assessments and

454
00:26:28.000 --> 00:26:32.650
But as we've seen, we can have
various user personas for one story.

455
00:26:32.650 --> 00:26:37.170
And we have to be able to articulate all
of our user personas because we've got to

00:26:37.170 --> 00:26:39.270
deliver a solution that meets them all.
>> You've

definitely given me
something to think about.

Hollywood and see how they do it?

this should go without really saying

this, but nevertheless,

287
00:16:00.072 --> 00:16:03.728
Relevance to the influences who
is the vision on the scope,

288
00:16:03.728 --> 00:16:08.810
every user story has to be relevant to
the vision of this particular project.

289
00:16:08.810 --> 00:16:17.022
If the project that we're working on is

290
00:16:17.022 --> 00:16:21.069
or a home grocery shopping experience,

00:16:21.069 --> 00:16:26.080
then the story should be
relevant to that vision.

292
00:16:26.080 --> 00:16:30.237
We shouldn't be compiling stories
that have got something to do with

293
00:16:30.237 --> 00:16:32.171
booking a train ticket online,

294
00:16:32.171 --> 00:16:36.560
for instance, that's not relevant
to this particular project.

295
00:16:36.560 --> 00:16:40.600
So the user stories have got
to be relevant to the vision.

296
00:16:40.600 --> 00:16:42.340
That's why I said it
should go without saying,

297
00:16:42.340 --> 00:16:44.390
really, cuz it should make perfect sense.

298
00:16:44.390 --> 00:16:48.003
But nevertheless,
I've seen some stories that I've got very,

00:16:48.003 --> 00:16:50.629
very tenuous links to the vision and
I thought,

00:16:50.629 --> 00:16:54.520
you just put that in there because
you wanted to really, didn't you?

301
00:16:54.520 --> 00:16:57.684
[LAUGH] Don't expect to have
a definitive set of stories up front,

302
00:16:57.684 --> 00:16:59.419
that's another important point.

303
00:16:59.419 --> 00:17:03.855
And it was something that we did
cover in our fundamentals class,

304
00:17:03.855 --> 00:17:05.558
because things change.

305
00:17:05.558 --> 00:17:07.567
That's the reason why we
have an agile project,

306
00:17:07.567 --> 00:17:09.720
because we understand that things change.

307
00:17:09.720 --> 00:17:14.617
So our stories are going to change
over time, and that's all right.

308
00:17:14.617 --> 00:17:19.590
We're gonna to bring in new stories over
the life of the project, and that's okay.

309
00:17:19.590 --> 00:17:24.122
So don't think that what you have
right now is cast in stone and

310
00:17:24.122 --> 00:17:29.920
that it should always be this set
of user stories and nothing else.

311
00:17:29.920 --> 00:17:34.728
No, that's not the case, and that set of
user stories is fine for right now, but

312
00:17:34.728 --> 00:17:37.909
at the end of it each sprint,
at the end of iteration,

313
00:17:37.909 --> 00:17:41.050
we're going to do a retrospective.

314
00:17:41.050 --> 00:17:44.550
And we're going to reevaluate the stories
that we still have outstanding and

315
00:17:44.550 --> 00:17:47.330
we're also gonna make sure
that they're still relevant.

316
00:17:47.330 --> 00:17:49.250
And therefore these things may change.

317
00:17:49.250 --> 00:17:55.360
>> Right, they certainly do,
on an insanely rapid pace sometimes.

318
00:17:55.360 --> 00:17:56.490
>> Yeah.

319
00:17:56.490 --> 00:17:58.635
>> Just before the show we
were talking about all this,

320
00:17:58.635 --> 00:18:01.771
at least I was talking about it, Jo may or
may not have been listening, but.

321
00:18:01.771 --> 00:18:03.215
>> [LAUGH]
>> I just said,

322
00:18:03.215 --> 00:18:08.084
I can barely keep up with even just day
to day tasks sometimes with the way

323
00:18:08.084 --> 00:18:11.511
companies are constantly
changing everything.

324
00:18:11.511 --> 00:18:13.660
And I-
>> I was listening.

325
00:18:13.660 --> 00:18:17.429
I was just rolling my eyes but
it was going in, kind of.

326
00:18:17.429 --> 00:18:20.733
>> Like some people, I feel bad for
them because it's more difficult for

327
00:18:20.733 --> 00:18:22.470
others to just keep up with all this.

328
00:18:22.470 --> 00:18:25.405
We gotta just be open and
adapt to all that change.

329
00:18:25.405 --> 00:18:26.381
>> We do, we do.

330
00:18:26.381 --> 00:18:28.433
And this is why we have
agile projects now,

331
00:18:28.433 --> 00:18:30.750
it's because we have to adapt to change.

332
00:18:30.750 --> 00:18:34.270
And actually what you said,
and I was listening.

333
00:18:34.270 --> 00:18:35.112
>> [LAUGH].

334
00:18:35.112 --> 00:18:37.450
>> [LAUGH] I promise I was listening.

335
00:18:37.450 --> 00:18:41.940
What you said makes perfect sense
in this agile environment because

336
00:18:43.050 --> 00:18:45.010
I mentioned user personas before.

337
00:18:45.010 --> 00:18:48.390
And what Cherokee had actually
said earlier on was that

338
00:18:48.390 --> 00:18:50.530
some people struggle with technology.

339
00:18:50.530 --> 00:18:54.350
And some people that are not exposed
to technology on a daily basis, and

340
00:18:54.350 --> 00:18:56.980
there are people that aren't,
then they'll struggle with technology.

341
00:18:56.980 --> 00:18:57.900
And simple things,

342
00:18:57.900 --> 00:19:02.910
like maybe paying bills,
work differently to how it used to work.

343
00:19:02.910 --> 00:19:08.430
And again, from an agile perspective when
you are the person that's responsible for

344
00:19:08.430 --> 00:19:10.640
developing that particular
functionality and

345
00:19:10.640 --> 00:19:14.670
developing that software, you've gotta
think about all of your user personas.

346
00:19:14.670 --> 00:19:15.740
And guess what?

347
00:19:15.740 --> 00:19:17.460
Right at the very
beginning of the project,

348
00:19:17.460 --> 00:19:20.160
you may not know all
of your user personas.

349
00:19:20.160 --> 00:19:25.170
And it may be because you're getting
feedback from your customers that actually

350
00:19:25.170 --> 00:19:30.070
gives you more information to create
another type of user persona.

351
00:19:30.070 --> 00:19:31.540
And, again, that's okay.

352
00:19:31.540 --> 00:19:34.370
We're in an agile environment,
we can do that.

353
00:19:34.370 --> 00:19:36.370
Still be the same stories, perhaps, but

354
00:19:36.370 --> 00:19:41.150
maybe we've got one more user persona
that we didn't realize that we had.

355
00:19:41.150 --> 00:19:42.400
And that's really important,

356
00:19:42.400 --> 00:19:45.840
is that in that agile environment,
we accommodate change.

357
00:19:47.390 --> 00:19:50.830
So when it comes to user stories,
and we spent quite a bit of time.

358
00:19:50.830 --> 00:19:56.208
And in fact, you should really go back to
our agile fundamentals course, because we

359
00:19:56.208 --> 00:20:01.830
looked at prioritizing and estimating user
stories in our agile fundamentals course.

360
00:20:01.830 --> 00:20:04.005
And we had some trick photography,

361
00:20:04.005 --> 00:20:07.460
we had some magic that
happened during that class.

362
00:20:07.460 --> 00:20:12.082
So I'm gonna ask you to go back to
that because we explain it in more

363
00:20:12.082 --> 00:20:13.183
detail there.

364
00:20:13.183 --> 00:20:15.217
But what we want to do, and

365
00:20:15.217 --> 00:20:19.109
the responsibility lies
with the product owner.

366
00:20:20.120 --> 00:20:24.828
And that responsibility is for sizing or

367
00:20:24.828 --> 00:20:27.876
estimating the stories.

368
00:20:27.876 --> 00:20:33.955
This is not the same as prioritizing,
prioritizing is completely different.

369
00:20:33.955 --> 00:20:37.831
Prioritizing is where we assign
a priority to each story.

370
00:20:37.831 --> 00:20:39.885
So maybe we've got 100 stories and

371
00:20:39.885 --> 00:20:44.745
we say, okay then, right, well, this story
is priority one, this one's priority two,

372
00:20:44.745 --> 00:20:49.355
this is priority three,
based on the urgency that is required.

373
00:20:50.510 --> 00:20:56.800
Whereas the sizing or estimating of
the story is based on the amount of

374
00:20:56.800 --> 00:21:03.850
effort that it is going to take
to deliver that particular story.

375
00:21:03.850 --> 00:21:08.584
So we look at this as
the relative size of the story.

376
00:21:08.584 --> 00:21:12.710
I don't like the use of the word bigness,
but I guess bigness works.

377
00:21:12.710 --> 00:21:15.390
It's based roughly on
the Fibonacci sequence and

378
00:21:15.390 --> 00:21:18.380
I'm glad our directors increased
this up to full size for us,

379
00:21:18.380 --> 00:21:21.760
because you'll see everything is
over on the right-hand side there.

380
00:21:21.760 --> 00:21:28.036
And the Fibonacci sequence is actually
just the sum of the two numbers before it,

381
00:21:28.036 --> 00:21:32.016
so 1 add 1 equals 2, and
then 2 add 1 equals 3.

382
00:21:32.016 --> 00:21:38.813
And then 3 add 2 equals 5, and
5 add 3 equals 8 and 8 add 5 equals 13.

383
00:21:38.813 --> 00:21:39.959
Yeah, you get the jist?

384
00:21:39.959 --> 00:21:42.584
>> Mm-hm.
>> Yeah, we're okay with that?

385
00:21:42.584 --> 00:21:46.950
Good, so it's roughly based
on the Fibonacci sequence.

386
00:21:46.950 --> 00:21:54.080
And the idea is that it's supposed
to avoid arguments over which

387
00:21:54.080 --> 00:21:59.242
story is going to take
the longest to achieve.

388
00:21:59.242 --> 00:22:02.235
It doesn't necessarily avoid arguments,
but

389
00:22:02.235 --> 00:22:07.618
as I've already said in previous episodes,
we should be working together as a team,

390
00:22:07.618 --> 00:22:10.715
so we all be valuing
each other's perspective.

391
00:22:10.715 --> 00:22:16.690
But we should be doing this in order
to estimate how long it's going to or

392
00:22:16.690 --> 00:22:20.310
how big each particular story is.

393
00:22:20.310 --> 00:22:23.800
And that will lead us then to estimate
how long its going to take to

394
00:22:23.800 --> 00:22:25.780
complete each story.

395
00:22:25.780 --> 00:22:29.330
We have to bear in mind that
in every single iteration,

396
00:22:30.350 --> 00:22:35.620
we only have a duration of between one and
four weeks for each iteration.

397
00:22:35.620 --> 00:22:37.494
So if you were to say, for instance,

398
00:22:37.494 --> 00:22:40.458
that we've got a story that we
think is going to take off and

399
00:22:40.458 --> 00:22:43.923
we might use ideal days and
we'll talk about that in a little while.

400
00:22:43.923 --> 00:22:48.838
But if you think that you've got
a story that might take you three

401
00:22:48.838 --> 00:22:52.388
weeks to complete,
are you now going to try and

402
00:22:52.388 --> 00:22:56.870
bring another two-week story
into that same iteration?

403
00:22:59.030 --> 00:23:00.123
There's no right or

404
00:23:00.123 --> 00:23:03.993
wrong answer to that cuz it depends
on how many developers you've got.

405
00:23:03.993 --> 00:23:07.972
But I would say be very, very careful
because when you say that it's gonna take

406
00:23:07.972 --> 00:23:10.760
three weeks to complete,
does that include testing?

407
00:23:12.350 --> 00:23:17.074
Probably not, and
you gotta test before you can measure any

408
00:23:17.074 --> 00:23:20.869
particular functionality for
its dominance.

409
00:23:20.869 --> 00:23:24.840
So it has to be tested, which will
take that three weeks into probably

410
00:23:24.840 --> 00:23:28.000
four weeks whilst we accommodate
the testing as well.

411
00:23:30.190 --> 00:23:33.222
So the product owner has
the responsibility for

412
00:23:33.222 --> 00:23:37.105
ensuring that this happens
along with the prioritization.

413
00:23:37.105 --> 00:23:41.414
But remember from a previous episode
when we looked at the characteristics of

414
00:23:41.414 --> 00:23:45.385
the product owner and we looked at
who the product owner would be?

415
00:23:45.385 --> 00:23:50.360
It's not necessary somebody with
a technical background, or not a hugely

416
00:23:50.360 --> 00:23:54.510
technical background anyway, it could
be somebody with a business background.

417
00:23:54.510 --> 00:23:58.413
It should certainly be somebody
that understands the business and

418
00:23:58.413 --> 00:24:01.069
understands what it is
the users want to see.

419
00:24:01.069 --> 00:24:06.266
That means that when it comes to
estimating, when it comes to sizing

420
00:24:06.266 --> 00:24:11.738
the stories, the product owner's role
is to make sure that the stories

421
00:24:11.738 --> 00:24:16.680
are sized and is to assist with
the prioritization of the story.

422
00:24:16.680 --> 00:24:23.350
But the product owner may not be in
a position to advise on the sizing,

423
00:24:23.350 --> 00:24:27.400
because the product owner may
not be a technical person.

424
00:24:29.690 --> 00:24:33.750
So for this particular episode,
for our part two on user

425
00:24:33.750 --> 00:24:38.750
stories then I want you to, as I've
already mentioned, go back into our

426
00:24:40.490 --> 00:24:45.160
episode in one of our previous
series on agile fundamentals.

427
00:24:45.160 --> 00:24:49.086
Yeah, and you will see how
we have used the magic of-

428
00:24:49.086 --> 00:24:50.076
>> [LAUGH].

429
00:24:50.076 --> 00:24:55.299
>> Of film [LAUGH] to bring
in some examples for you.

430
00:24:55.299 --> 00:24:57.454
>> Yeah,
that was pretty cool cuz like you said,

431
00:24:57.454 --> 00:25:01.049
and even if that product owner doesn't,
the way that we talked about doing it

432
00:25:01.049 --> 00:25:03.845
involves the actual developers
to help give their inputs.

433
00:25:03.845 --> 00:25:07.907
So that technical experience is
compensated for by the actual developers.

434
00:25:07.907 --> 00:25:11.165
>> Right, I'd expect the developers
to be able to do this.

435
00:25:11.165 --> 00:25:13.352
>> Right.
>> This is the product owner is the person

436
00:25:13.352 --> 00:25:14.899
that makes sure it happens, but

437
00:25:14.899 --> 00:25:18.240
the developers are people
that actually perform that.

438
00:25:18.240 --> 00:25:21.630
So in our next episode when we come back,
we're going to be looking

439
00:25:21.630 --> 00:25:25.850
a little bit more at planning and most
specifically our five levels of planning.

440
00:25:25.850 --> 00:25:28.370
>> All right, Jo, thank you so
much for being here and thank you for

441
00:25:28.370 --> 00:25:29.040
being here as well.

442
00:25:29.040 --> 00:25:30.540
But for now, let's sign out.

443
00:25:30.540 --> 00:25:31.961
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

444
00:25:31.961 --> 00:25:32.740
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

00:25:32.740 --> 00:25:35.702
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

[MUSIC]

447
00:25:41.181 --> 00:25:44.272
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

00:01:59.827 --> 00:02:03.787

that, it's one of the things that I want

00:02:03.787 --> 00:02:07.057

00:28:23.760 --> 00:28:25.281
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

515
00:28:25.281 --> 00:28:32.031
[MUSIC]

516
00:28:32.031 --> 00:28:34.091
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

1

2
00:00:01.434 --> 00:00:06.501
I'm your host, Don-

3
00:00:06.501 --> 00:00:08.438
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.438 --> 00:00:13.426
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.
>> Welcome everyone to

5
00:00:13.426 --> 00:00:16.060
your Agile Product Owner series.

6
00:00:16.060 --> 00:00:18.070
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.070 --> 00:00:21.880
We've been looking at the five levels of
planning and in this show specifically,

8
00:00:21.880 --> 00:00:24.090
we'll be taking a look at our release.

9
00:00:24.090 --> 00:00:27.090
And with us today back in studios,
we have Ms. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:27.090 --> 00:00:29.170
How is going today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great, thank you,

11
00:00:29.170 --> 00:00:32.739
Cherokee, how are you?
>> I'm doing all right, thanks for asking.

12
00:00:32.739 --> 00:00:36.445
I'm slowly coming down
off of my sugar cupcake

13
00:00:36.445 --> 00:00:41.205
high that I was on from the last show.
>> Yeah, that was too much sugar,

14
00:00:41.205 --> 00:00:42.821
too much sugar for the last show.
>> [LAUGH]

15
00:00:42.821 --> 00:00:44.874
>> I don't think she can even remember

16
00:00:44.874 --> 00:00:48.480
the last episode.
>> It was just like a whirlwind and

17
00:00:48.480 --> 00:00:51.270
those first couple of levels,
they were actually vision and

18
00:00:51.270 --> 00:00:54.648
road map.
>> Okay now I'm impressed and perhaps we

19
00:00:54.648 --> 00:00:57.762
should be giving her more sugar.
>> [LAUGH]

20
00:00:57.762 --> 00:00:59.055
>> Because you're right,

21
00:00:59.055 --> 00:01:02.998
the first couple of levels where our
vision and our road map, and then in this

22
00:01:02.998 --> 00:01:07.160
particular episode we're going to
be looking at our release planning.

23
00:01:07.160 --> 00:01:10.650
And then in subsequent episodes,
we're gonna further into planning for

24
00:01:10.650 --> 00:01:11.590
the iterations.

25
00:01:11.590 --> 00:01:14.800
And of course our daily planning,
which is our daily stand up.

26
00:01:14.800 --> 00:01:19.060
But for this, we're just gonna look
at the planning for a release.

27
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:22.590
So in our last episode, previous episode,
we looked at the vision,

28
00:01:22.590 --> 00:01:26.170
that high level elevator pitch vision.

29
00:01:26.170 --> 00:01:29.915
And by the way, we call that
a lift all right, it's a lift.

30
00:01:29.915 --> 00:01:33.885
But then that wouldn't sound right,
actually, I like the term elevator pitch,

31
00:01:33.885 --> 00:01:36.053
rather than a lift pitch.
>> A lift pitch, yeah.

32
00:01:36.053 --> 00:01:37.875
>> Kinda sounds clumsy, right?

33
00:01:37.875 --> 00:01:41.670
[LAUGH] So we looked at our
elevator pitch and our vision, and

34
00:01:41.670 --> 00:01:45.150
then we looked at our road map,

35
00:01:45.150 --> 00:01:50.822
which was our three month out plan And
here now we're looking at a release plan.

36
00:01:50.822 --> 00:01:54.554
And a release plan is something that,
well remember what release is,

37
00:01:54.554 --> 00:01:56.769
we looked at this in previous episodes and

38
00:01:56.769 --> 00:02:00.082
we also looked at this in our
ITIL fundamental series as well.

39
00:02:00.082 --> 00:02:05.125
And a release of course is,
it's what you release to the businesses,

40
00:02:05.125 --> 00:02:07.850
what you release to the user.

41
00:02:07.850 --> 00:02:11.960
So it's what the user sees and
a release can contain one or

42
00:02:11.960 --> 00:02:15.870
more iterations and
sometimes we might wait to have maybe

43
00:02:15.870 --> 00:02:18.880
three iterations before we
actually perform a release.

44
00:02:18.880 --> 00:02:23.750
Which means that if each iteration
is say four weeks, then that

45
00:02:23.750 --> 00:02:29.180
release could take three months
itself to actually be implemented.

46
00:02:29.180 --> 00:02:33.180
The goal of the release plan though,

47
00:02:33.180 --> 00:02:37.920
cuz we gotta plan it before we do it,
is to actually prioritize the features and

48
00:02:37.920 --> 00:02:40.797
complete the estimates and
plan for our releases.

49
00:02:40.797 --> 00:02:45.610
You see I've already mentioned that
a release contains multiple iterations or

50
00:02:45.610 --> 00:02:47.170
sprints, if you want to call them that.

51
00:02:48.480 --> 00:02:51.150
But who's to say what's
going to be in each sprint?

52
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:55.160
And who's to say what that
release is going to look like?

53
00:02:55.160 --> 00:02:58.590
Well, this is done at
the beginning remember?

54
00:02:58.590 --> 00:03:02.570
In our previous episode we had to
prioritize our user's stories and

55
00:03:02.570 --> 00:03:07.140
we had to also estimate exactly
how long it was going to take.

56
00:03:07.140 --> 00:03:09.528
Well all right,
you can't estimate exactly.

57
00:03:09.528 --> 00:03:12.900
But you had to estimate how long it was
going to take to perform each user's

58
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:13.920
story.

59
00:03:13.920 --> 00:03:17.520
And it's the product owner who
then at that point in time,

60
00:03:17.520 --> 00:03:23.480
they will then decide which stories
are going to appear in which iteration.

61
00:03:23.480 --> 00:03:26.530
And then of course at the end of each
iteration, and we'll look at this

62
00:03:26.530 --> 00:03:31.270
in a little while, but we conduct
a review at the end of the iteration.

63
00:03:31.270 --> 00:03:35.890
And that review will allow us
to see what's been completed,

64
00:03:35.890 --> 00:03:41.120
what hasn't been completed and then what
we should include in the next iteration.

65
00:03:41.120 --> 00:03:45.050
Our release plan then really lists out

66
00:03:45.050 --> 00:03:50.230
what iterations should be
in each individual release.

67
00:03:50.230 --> 00:03:54.130
So what piece of functionality
am I going to deliver?

68
00:03:55.170 --> 00:03:57.710
That's what should be in our release plan.

69
00:03:57.710 --> 00:04:01.600
So the release states,
it says that if they're fixed,

70
00:04:01.600 --> 00:04:07.440
plan out what features will be
included based on the team's velocity.

71
00:04:07.440 --> 00:04:09.860
Velocity, well we know
that that means speed.

72
00:04:09.860 --> 00:04:13.000
But it's based on what we think

73
00:04:14.470 --> 00:04:19.600
the team can develop in that period
of time, based on what we think

74
00:04:19.600 --> 00:04:24.364
the team can develop for each iteration.
>> I remember,

75
00:04:24.364 --> 00:04:28.163
that's the time when I found out that
I wasn't as productive as I thought I

76
00:04:28.163 --> 00:04:29.460
was.
>> [LAUGH] Right.

77
00:04:29.460 --> 00:04:32.177
>> Or ideal days when I learned that term.

78
00:04:32.177 --> 00:04:32.861
>> Exactly and

79
00:04:32.861 --> 00:04:36.139
we'll look at this when we
look at iteration planning and

80
00:04:36.139 --> 00:04:40.598
planning out those ideal days and what
we can do to help with those ideal days.

81
00:04:40.598 --> 00:04:44.253
But in a nut shell, we looked at
our productive time and our not so

82
00:04:44.253 --> 00:04:48.722
productive time and we look to do a lot
of our development work in our productive

83
00:04:48.722 --> 00:04:52.680
time because that's when we're
being productive funnily enough.

84
00:04:52.680 --> 00:04:56.313
And then our not productive time we
shouldn't beat ourselves up about the fact

85
00:04:56.313 --> 00:04:58.510
we're not productive during that time.

86
00:04:58.510 --> 00:05:03.472
We should just make sure that we don't
actually do any development during that

87
00:05:03.472 --> 00:05:08.650
non productive time, because we may end
up redoing it and that's not efficient.

88
00:05:08.650 --> 00:05:12.396
So here is where we gotta be honest.

89
00:05:12.396 --> 00:05:16.021
When it comes to release planning and
when it comes to working out velocity and

90
00:05:16.021 --> 00:05:19.367
when it comes to working out what
we're gonna include in each release,

91
00:05:19.367 --> 00:05:20.567
we've gotta be honest.

92
00:05:20.567 --> 00:05:25.607
We've really got to look at
what a team is capable of.

93
00:05:25.607 --> 00:05:28.120
We've estimated user stories.

94
00:05:28.120 --> 00:05:35.070
We've estimated how much development work
it should take, if they were ideal days.

95
00:05:35.070 --> 00:05:38.413
And an ideal day is a day where
we do eight hours worth of

96
00:05:38.413 --> 00:05:40.055
solid development work.

97
00:05:40.055 --> 00:05:43.325
That's eight hours worth of solid
development work without any

98
00:05:43.325 --> 00:05:45.390
interruptions during that eight days.

99
00:05:45.390 --> 00:05:48.882
That means no going and
getting a cup of tea nor a coffee or

100
00:05:48.882 --> 00:05:50.752
whatever else that you want.

101
00:05:50.752 --> 00:05:53.812
It means no taking a lunch break,
it means no answering your telephone or

102
00:05:53.812 --> 00:05:55.840
anything else that you have to do.

103
00:05:55.840 --> 00:05:59.320
Well how often does that happen
in real life, it doesn't.

104
00:06:01.110 --> 00:06:05.400
So we have to know what it is we
are going to deliver in each release and

105
00:06:05.400 --> 00:06:09.390
we have to be honest in our estimations.

106
00:06:09.390 --> 00:06:15.220
And be honest as to what we can seriously
achieve within a certain time span.

107
00:06:15.220 --> 00:06:20.480
So when we start off with our release
plan, we generally know the scope.

108
00:06:20.480 --> 00:06:24.585
And I even tell you there,
some of the features are fixed.

109
00:06:24.585 --> 00:06:29.311
And estimate well,
we're gonna have to map out a release

110
00:06:29.311 --> 00:06:34.050
plan based on how quickly we
can produce those features.

111
00:06:34.050 --> 00:06:36.142
So we can start off with two approaches.

112
00:06:36.142 --> 00:06:40.970
We can either say okay, we're gonna really
say every two months in which case then we

113
00:06:40.970 --> 00:06:44.405
have to work out exactly what
we can fit in every two months.

114
00:06:44.405 --> 00:06:48.130
Or we say, right I'm gonna
release based on feature and

115
00:06:48.130 --> 00:06:50.775
I'm gonna release once
this feature is complete.

116
00:06:50.775 --> 00:06:55.684
In which case, then we have to go back and
estimate how productive the team is and

117
00:06:55.684 --> 00:07:00.172
see how long it's going to take to
complete those particular features.

118
00:07:00.172 --> 00:07:04.650
There's no right or wrong way, you can do
your estimations whichever way you want.

119
00:07:04.650 --> 00:07:06.440
You can either estimate
based on feature or

120
00:07:06.440 --> 00:07:11.250
you can estimate based on date and
this is when we will release.

121
00:07:11.250 --> 00:07:15.490
It's entirely up to you as to which way
you do that, but you do have to do it.

122
00:07:16.540 --> 00:07:18.150
You have to use a rough estimate.

123
00:07:19.210 --> 00:07:21.361
So when you're reviewing features,

124
00:07:21.361 --> 00:07:25.268
you have to use a rough estimate as
to how long it's going to take you.

125
00:07:25.268 --> 00:07:28.097
So what I mean,
we use things like T-shirt sizes.

126
00:07:28.097 --> 00:07:29.184
Is it a small?

127
00:07:29.184 --> 00:07:30.770
Is it medium?

128
00:07:30.770 --> 00:07:31.605
Is it large?

129
00:07:31.605 --> 00:07:36.226
And by the way, the numbers that are in
there, you'll devise the numbers, not me.

130
00:07:36.226 --> 00:07:42.377
You devise those and we've got say 20,
40, 60in terms of man out.

131
00:07:42.377 --> 00:07:46.037
We've also gotta plan for the unknowns.

132
00:07:46.037 --> 00:07:50.209
That's the telephone calls,
that's the call into the meeting,

133
00:07:50.209 --> 00:07:54.679
that's being dragged off to somewhere
else to have a conversation with

134
00:07:54.679 --> 00:07:58.939
somebody because you need
clarification about a certain feature.

135
00:07:58.939 --> 00:08:03.164
That's the fact that no you've suddenly
got 100 e-mails or somebody's Come and

136
00:08:03.164 --> 00:08:05.750
tapped you on the shoulder and
said as they do with me?

137
00:08:05.750 --> 00:08:11.504
Could you actually finish those
descriptions please, for those episodes?

138
00:08:11.504 --> 00:08:13.803
All of those unknowns that
you weren't expecting,

139
00:08:13.803 --> 00:08:17.000
that you think to yourself well,
I've already got 101 things to do.

140
00:08:17.000 --> 00:08:18.220
How I'm I gonna do that?

141
00:08:19.640 --> 00:08:22.000
All of those need to be estimated.

142
00:08:22.000 --> 00:08:24.350
So plan for those unknowns,
it's gonna happen.

143
00:08:24.350 --> 00:08:28.320
And this is when we get into those ideal
days that Cherokee was talking about.

144
00:08:28.320 --> 00:08:32.690
And looking at,
not just when's our productive time, but

145
00:08:32.690 --> 00:08:37.380
really strictly, how many hours
a day do we expect to be productive?

146
00:08:37.380 --> 00:08:39.177
I can't answer that for you.

147
00:08:39.177 --> 00:08:43.884
When I think about how many hours
a day we expect to be productive, and

148
00:08:43.884 --> 00:08:48.428
I wonder how many hours a day are spent
actually tying up all of those

149
00:08:48.428 --> 00:08:52.020
loose ends that just come
along during the day.

150
00:08:52.020 --> 00:08:54.990
And how productive are we really?

151
00:08:54.990 --> 00:08:58.720
The idea is that we want the team
to keep a sustainable pace.

152
00:08:58.720 --> 00:09:04.820
So, we want to have sustained
development throughout that time.

153
00:09:04.820 --> 00:09:08.330
So, from the start of our first situation,
right away through to

154
00:09:08.330 --> 00:09:13.780
our actual release state, we wanna
ensure that the development is steady.

155
00:09:13.780 --> 00:09:15.290
Don't forget testing as well.

156
00:09:15.290 --> 00:09:19.850
We've got to ensure that we do
testing too within that time span.

157
00:09:21.000 --> 00:09:24.970
We've got to release frequently,
it's not just a one off thing.

158
00:09:24.970 --> 00:09:27.190
And that's what we call
a Waterfall approach, right?

159
00:09:27.190 --> 00:09:29.300
We released frequently.

160
00:09:29.300 --> 00:09:32.010
So it might be after every iteration.

161
00:09:32.010 --> 00:09:33.480
I wouldn't recommend that.

162
00:09:33.480 --> 00:09:35.560
It might be after every
two to three iterations.

163
00:09:36.750 --> 00:09:39.774
I certainly wouldn't want you to
be releasing after every six or

164
00:09:39.774 --> 00:09:42.966
seven iterations because again,
that's a waterfall approach and

165
00:09:42.966 --> 00:09:44.988
you're not really building up momentum.

166
00:09:44.988 --> 00:09:48.755
And if you've had seven or
eight iterations in three months,

167
00:09:48.755 --> 00:09:52.170
then that's really going some,
that's all I can say.

168
00:09:52.170 --> 00:09:55.980
Either well done, or my goodness,
how are you coping with the chaos?

169
00:09:55.980 --> 00:09:57.740
I'm not too sure which that would be.

170
00:09:58.850 --> 00:10:04.753
But remember, we have to understand
what a definition of done means.

171
00:10:04.753 --> 00:10:08.718
In other words, when do we sign
off on that particular release and

172
00:10:08.718 --> 00:10:10.530
say yes, that's good to go.

173
00:10:11.630 --> 00:10:14.580
So we plan all of that,
both our technical teams,

174
00:10:14.580 --> 00:10:18.220
in other words our development teams,
but also the business team as well.

175
00:10:18.220 --> 00:10:21.920
Go back to the episode where we were
looking at the product owner and

176
00:10:21.920 --> 00:10:25.160
who the product owner should be, and
you'll see that the product owner

177
00:10:25.160 --> 00:10:27.600
should be somebody with a good
understanding of the business.

178
00:10:29.370 --> 00:10:35.060
And our score master is gonna help us with
deciding exactly who has what skills and

179
00:10:35.060 --> 00:10:38.510
how quickly they can do
development work as well.

180
00:10:38.510 --> 00:10:42.805
So between the two, you should be able
to come up with a rough estimate,

181
00:10:42.805 --> 00:10:45.169
but you should also get the business and

182
00:10:45.169 --> 00:10:48.698
any other technical stuff
involved wherever you need to.

183
00:10:48.698 --> 00:10:54.440
The backlog management,
our backlog is our list of things to do.

184
00:10:56.230 --> 00:11:01.220
We've got there, we've got stories, we've
got defects that may come from a backlog.

185
00:11:01.220 --> 00:11:06.490
We've got nonfunctional requirements
that may be on our backlog as well.

186
00:11:06.490 --> 00:11:10.730
A backlog is our list of things to do,
so simple as that.

187
00:11:10.730 --> 00:11:16.570
Now with every single iteration,
a backlog will change.

188
00:11:16.570 --> 00:11:19.680
Because with every single iteration,
it doesn't matter how well we

189
00:11:19.680 --> 00:11:23.680
plan that iteration, there are going
to be defects that come out of testing.

190
00:11:23.680 --> 00:11:27.560
There are going to be nonfunctional
requirements that may be difficult to

191
00:11:27.560 --> 00:11:29.260
estimate for instance.

192
00:11:29.260 --> 00:11:33.930
And with every single iteration,
as much as we like to plan for

193
00:11:33.930 --> 00:11:35.970
each iteration and
we'd like to get it right, and

194
00:11:35.970 --> 00:11:38.970
we'd like to deliver absolutely
everything that we set out to deliver,

195
00:11:38.970 --> 00:11:42.370
there has to be an understanding
in Agile that we don't do that.

196
00:11:43.580 --> 00:11:46.345
I'm not saying that every
single iteration is wrong.

197
00:11:46.345 --> 00:11:50.510
[LAUGH] I'm not saying that we never
do anything in any iteration, or

198
00:11:50.510 --> 00:11:54.810
we never achieve our goals, but
what I'm saying is that we're realistic.

199
00:11:56.430 --> 00:11:57.450
That's agile.

200
00:11:57.450 --> 00:12:01.690
Agile means that we are adaptable and
so we're realistic.

201
00:12:01.690 --> 00:12:05.590
And with every iteration,
we have to revisit our backlog, and

202
00:12:05.590 --> 00:12:09.770
then we have to prioritize again or
reprioritize.

203
00:12:09.770 --> 00:12:14.130
The other thing, when it comes to
backlog management is that, and

204
00:12:14.130 --> 00:12:18.970
this is something that we don't have
to think about too, it's insuring

205
00:12:18.970 --> 00:12:22.560
that we've actually got enough stories for
the development team to work on.

206
00:12:22.560 --> 00:12:26.130
You don't want your development team
sitting there twiddling their thumbs.

207
00:12:27.360 --> 00:12:31.130
And I wonder how often that happens
actually that we run out of stories.

208
00:12:31.130 --> 00:12:34.170
What do you think we should
do if we run out of stories?

209
00:12:34.170 --> 00:12:38.270
>> I don't know but I think

210
00:12:38.270 --> 00:12:42.550
that if that happened here at ITProTV,
they should probably go on a field trip

211
00:12:42.550 --> 00:12:45.152
because those guys, they worked so well.
>> [LAUGH]

212
00:12:45.152 --> 00:12:46.026
>> Like they work all the time.

213
00:12:46.026 --> 00:12:49.510
I don't ever see them twiddling.
>> [LAUGH]

214
00:12:49.510 --> 00:12:50.925
>> Maybe they're just really,

215
00:12:50.925 --> 00:12:52.792
really good at pretending to work, but

216
00:12:52.792 --> 00:12:55.611
I don't think that's the case.
>> [LAUGH] Well I do see

217
00:12:55.611 --> 00:12:58.890
Tim wandering around
with his fidget spinner.

218
00:12:58.890 --> 00:13:00.090
Maybe that's what it is.
>> [LAUGH]

219
00:13:00.090 --> 00:13:01.010
>> Maybe it's just that he's not

220
00:13:01.010 --> 00:13:02.971
got enough to do.
>> Yeah,

221
00:13:02.971 --> 00:13:05.370
no I say field trip.
>> You say field trip?

222
00:13:05.370 --> 00:13:06.200
>> Yeah, go ahead and

223

[LAUGH] So we have to establish

00:13:47.520 --> 00:13:51.880

00:14:07.750 --> 00:14:11.090

00:14:15.640 --> 00:14:19.850

00:14:19.850 --> 00:14:23.500

245
00:14:30.260 --> 00:14:33.020

246
00:14:33.020 --> 00:14:37.980

00:14:42.470 --> 00:14:46.158

254
00:15:07.860 --> 00:15:11.930

00:23:47.632 --> 00:23:52.138

00:24:04.011 --> 00:24:08.846

00:24:08.846 --> 00:24:13.539

00:24:13.539 --> 00:24:16.810

419
00:24:16.810 --> 00:24:20.710

00:24:21.770 --> 00:24:25.730

421
00:24:25.730 --> 00:24:31.420

00:24:31.420 --> 00:24:35.180

00:24:45.440 --> 00:24:49.870

00:24:49.870 --> 00:24:52.930

00:24:52.930 --> 00:24:57.800
So we use this particular tool,
this particular review as a vehicle

00:25:02.762 --> 00:25:09.910

00:25:20.730 --> 00:25:27.350

00:25:27.350 --> 00:25:31.960

if something has gone wrong,

00:25:31.960 --> 00:25:35.930

either inadequate planning or

436
00:25:35.930 --> 00:25:38.760
the fact that we didn't add
something into the contingency.

437
00:25:38.760 --> 00:25:42.620
And therefore, we've gotta plan for
it better next time.

438
00:25:42.620 --> 00:25:47.116
This is not about apportioning blame,
this is not about pointing fingers, and

439
00:25:47.116 --> 00:25:48.604
I want to emphasize that.

00:25:48.604 --> 00:25:51.460
This is not what the review is about.

00:25:51.460 --> 00:25:56.120

00:26:07.230 --> 00:26:12.550
the review should not be used as a vehicle

00:26:12.550 --> 00:26:15.840

00:26:15.840 --> 00:26:19.520

00:26:40.410 --> 00:26:45.220

00:26:45.220 --> 00:26:49.820

00:26:49.820 --> 00:26:54.042

00:26:54.042 --> 00:26:58.080

00:26:58.080 --> 00:27:01.080

00:27:01.080 --> 00:27:06.280

00:27:07.364 --> 00:27:12.410

00:27:38.860 --> 00:27:42.070
